text: well this is Hmong door it's the town
near the Bangladesh border that's been
the epicenter of the violence that has
erupted in northern reclines state we've
come on a rather long and arduous
journey to get here on a government tour
and the government has brought us here
it doesn't normally allow journalists or
any foreigners into this region without
special permission because it wants to
challenge the narrative that the rest of
the world is hearing from the many
refugees the tens of thousands have been
fleeing into Bangladesh and so they've
been taking us to various sites showing
us examples of destruction and letting
us talk to people and all of them are
sticking to the same story which it is
the Muslim militants who've infiltrated
ro Hindu communities of course they
don't use the word Ranger it's pretty
much banned in this part of the world
but they're saying that the Muslim
communities were infiltrated by these
militants and it was the militants
themselves who burnt down these villages
what you can see here is the remains of
perhaps four or five houses apparently
lived in by Muslim inhabitants who are
now being looked after next door in the
Buddhist temple that you can see behind
me it's very hard for us to challenge
this narrative everyone was speaking to
we're doing so well in the company of
police heavily armed police and
government officials we have heard some
dissenting views when we've been able to
talk quietly to people but this is the
message the government wants to get
across that it is not their fault the
security forces have denied any abuses
at all all those allegations of rape and
of shooting and they're saying that all
of the burning the hundreds of villages
that have been burnt down every part of
it is the responsibility of the
militants themselves and nothing to do
with the government I think it'll be
very hard for people to believe that but
that's the line we're hearing here
mondo itself feels very fearful it's
quiet the shops are all shut there's a
very heavy security presence there is a
sense that the violence that has run
over this area on the border with
Bangladesh is not over yet
you
